\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Callback timer implementation (ctimer) 

\begin{DoxyCopyright}{Copyright}
Copyright (c) 2006, Swedish Institute of Computer Science. 
\end{DoxyCopyright}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{License\+:}
This file is released under the 3-\/Clause BSD License.~\newline
 \href{https://opensource.org/license/bsd-3-clause/}{\texttt{ https\+://opensource.\+org/license/bsd-\/3-\/clause/}}
\end{DoxyParagraph}
In computer programming, a callback or callback function is any reference to executable code that is passed as an argument to another piece of code; that code is expected to call back (execute) the callback function as part of its job. This execution may be immediate as in a synchronous callback, or it might happen at a later point in time as in an asynchronous callback. They are also called blocking and non-\/blocking.

\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Callback_(computer_programming)}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Callback\+\_\+(computer\+\_\+programming)}}

Callback timer callbacks are asynchronous callbacks.

The callback function gets invoked in the context of the process that started the callback timer.
